chapter.title: Approaches to teaching Workforce Preparation Activities and Employability Skills
chapter.content:
Through the activity completed in Session 1, you’ve observed that there may be room in your lessons to add or amplify workforce preparation activities. The end goal is to ensure that opportunities are present for students to practice, demonstrate and reflect on workforce preparation and employability skills. These opportunities can be embedded throughout your curriculum and instruction. Here we’ll explore strategies to align your instruction with the overarching goals of workforce preparation.

chapter.title: Deeper learning competencies
chapter.content:
As discussed earlier, the workforce preparation activities described in WIOA are well-aligned with principles of deeper learning and can be served by similar instructional strategies.

There is no single definition of deeper learning. In the broadest sense, deeper learning is defined as a set of competencies organized across three domains[3]:

  • cognitive domain (mastery and application of core academic content, critical and creative thinking and problem solving, constructing and evaluating evidence-based arguments, and systems thinking);
  • interpersonal domain (collaboration and teamwork, effective communication, leadership); and
  • intrapersonal domain (learning how to learn, learning mind-sets, intellectual openness, ability to transfer and apply knowledge to solve new problems in new situations)

[3] Heller, R., Wolfe, R.E., & Stenberg, A. (Eds.). Rethinking Readiness: Deeper Learning for College, Work, and Life. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. Pgs. vi, vii,

chapter.title: The deeper learning process
chapter.content:
The National Research Council (NRC) summarizes the process of deeper learning as one “through which a person becomes capable of taking what was learned in one situation and applying it to new situations—in other words, learning for ‘transfer.’[4]  

The concept of deeper learning moves away from rote learning of academic content and procedures and re-centers learning on knowing how to tackle new, and disparate problems, by recognizing when, why, and how to use (apply) academic content, knowledge, and skills more broadly and flexibly.[5] At its core, this ability to transfer and apply knowledge is what distinguishes novices from experts, and this ability takes time and practice, especially practice that is supported with feedback.


[4] James W. Pellegrino and Margaret L. Hilton, et. al. Education for Life and Work: Guide for Practitioners. Washington, DC.: National Research Council, 2012. Pg. 3.

[5] Ibid. pgs. 3,12

chapter.title: Research concerning 21st century skills
chapter.content:
According to the National Research Council, research shows that problem solving, critical thinking, and other 21st century skills’ are best developed in the context of teaching and learning academic subjects. In fact, research shows that these skills are key to helping students truly master academic subject matter. Incorporating workforce preparation activities that focus on problem solving into academic instruction has the potential to deepen, reinforce, and add rigor to academic skill building, rather than detract from or diffuse academic learning. Conversely, instruction that promotes deeper learning can serve as a pathway and pedagogical approach to cultivating workforce preparation and employability skills.

To date, much of the attention on deeper learning has been in the context of secondary education. However, the kinds of critical thinking and analytical skills fostered by the concept of deeper learning holds significant potential for college and career readiness outcomes.[6]

Continue to Six Key Practices to Promote Deeper Learning.
